author: thecooldown.com - Zachary Ehrmann
title: Researchers issue urgent warning after witnessing disturbing behavioral shift in ocean species: 'It's really just horrific' | Flipboard
text:
Researchers issue urgent warning after witnessing disturbing behavioral shift in ocean species: 'It's really just horrific' Thousands of gray whales are migrating north from Mexico's Baja lagoons in visibly emaciated condition, with some so thin their ribs are protruding. â€¦
thecooldown.com - Zachary Ehrmann â€¢ 1h

author: Paul Chalk
title: Derek Adams is upbeat despite latest Ross County call-off
text:
Ross County Derek Adams is upbeat despite latest Ross County call-off Premiership clashes against Hearts and Aberdeen have the fired-up Staggies in upbeat mood after fixtures against Hibs and Rangers were postponed.
By Paul Chalk December 28 2023, 10.30pm Share Derek Adams is upbeat despite latest Ross County call-off Share via Facebook Twitter Whatsapp Messenger Linkedin Email Post link https://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/fp/sport/football/ross-county/6309617/derek-adams-is-upbeat-despite-latest-ross-county-call-off/ Copy Link Ross County manager Derek Adams. Image: SNS Group
Ross County boss Derek Adams is confident a second successive call-off wonâ€™t affect his players as they seek to defeat Hearts at Tynecastle this weekend.
Last Saturdayâ€™s home Premiership match against Hibs was postponed due to a waterlogged pitch.
Then, on Wednesday, with County stuck on the snowbound A9, the SPFL, aided by Police Scotlandâ€™s advice, opted to postpone their match against Rangers at Ibrox.
It means the Staggies have not played since their last-gasp 1-0 home defeat to Dundee on December 16.
Now they prepare to face in-form Hearts at Tynecastle, fresh from the Jambosâ€™ dramatic 1-0 derby win at Hibs, thanks to a winner from Lawrence Shankland.
The impact of Storm Gerrit on Wednesday caused major travel trouble throughout part of Scotland, with Aberdeen v Motherwell also called off.
The A9 was shut both ways due to heavy snowfall at the Drumochter and Dalwhinnie sections, with flooding soon after affecting the Ballinluig and Dunkeld areas.
Steven Ferguson says A9 closure made it impossible for Ross County to continue journey for Rangers match
Although Rangers and County wanted the game on, there was an agreement that safety came first for fans of both sides travelling as well as the visitors who were facing a losing battle to reach Glasgow.
Extra training time was real positive Adams looked at the positive side of the situation as he gained extra training time on Thursday.
He said: â€œIt was the correct decision (to postpone the match).
â€œThe league had to make that decision on Wednesday afternoon, because as we all know the A9 was closed for much of the day and it was going to be impossible not just for us to get to the game, but for supporters from both sides to get to the game.
â€œIt was the correct decision. Weâ€™re all disappointed the game was off, but there was no other decision the league could have made.
â€œItâ€™s just something that you have to deal with â€“ itâ€™s not too big of a problem.
â€œWeâ€™ve been able to train in Dingwall, but from our point of view weâ€™ve missed two games against Hibernian and Rangers.
â€œWhat it has done is allow us some training time.â€
Players will be ready for hectic run With just 17 league matches played, only Aberdeen with 16, have played fewer fixtures than County, with games stacking up for after the winter break which follows this Tuesdayâ€™s clash between the north rivals in Dingwall.
Adams says his players will relish rather than dread the packed schedule following their Scottish Cup tie against Partick Thistle on January 20.
He said: â€œWeâ€™re obviously going to go back into a period at the end of January and February where weâ€™re playing on Saturdays and Tuesdays for a bit.
â€œThat will be nice, because the players probably enjoy that more than training.
â€œWeâ€™ll get a period of rest from games for two and a half weeks, but weâ€™ll be training hard in that period too.â€
ðŸŽŸï¸ Tickets for Saturday's trip to face Heart of Midlothian are still available.
Purchase here ðŸ‘‰ https://t.co/WWcxaUX49E pic.twitter.com/6VxKEafZNf
â€” Ross County FC (@RossCounty) December 28, 2023
County are keen to test hosts Hearts Shankland is hogging the headlines due to his goal exploits, but Hearts also have three clean sheets in a row as they sit third in the top-flight.
Adams, however, backs County to ask questions of Steven Naismithâ€™s side in the capital.
He said: â€œWe have to go there and create opportunities, take the ball and get into that final third.
â€œWe obviously have to deal with the threat of not only Lawrence Shankland, but the other players who have done well for them this season.
â€œThey are third in the league for a reason, and they have done well in the league, and in Europe, over a number of seasons.â€
Seven-point haul so far for Adams Since Adams replaced Malky Mackay as the manager of County for his third spell in charge, they have taken seven points out of 15.
A 0-0 draw against Kilmarnock preceded 1-0 and 3-0 wins over St Mirren and Motherwell .
St Mirrenâ€™s 2-0 win against County in Paisley was Adamsâ€™ first defeat since the start of his third spell in charge then the sore 1-0 loss to Dundee kept the Dingwall team on 17 points.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: HISD Analyses the Teachers it Has Left
text:
By Margaret Downing ,
3 hours ago
If half of the 2,600 teachers who left Houston ISD in June and July were rated in the bottom two proficiency categories by the district is this a sign that they were bad teachers or that they just couldnâ€™t get with Superintendent Mike Milesâ€™ programs?
Should parents breathe a sigh of relief or in some cases continue to question the policies of the new administration?
And as to why the more highly rated teachers, including those judged to have turned in â€œexemplaryâ€ performances, quit their jobs with HISD, itâ€™s not known. As explained by Jessica Neyman, HISDâ€™s Chief Human Resources Officer at Thursday nightâ€™s school board meeting, the Miles administration is continuing the previous practice of leaving it up to the departing employees to ask for an exit interview.
For his part, Miles pointed to his data showing 83 percent of the higher rated teachers staying with the district as evidence that HISD is building a more proficient teacher force. "The higher the instructional proficiency of the teachers, the higher the retention rate."
The departures were higher than historic numbers, 2,696 compared to 2,000, but he added that 1,400 of those teachers had been told they were being brought in for "file review" in the spring meaning they knew their continued job prospects weren't stellar. "Most of those teachers decided to resign," Miles said, before going through that process.
In a power-packed evening there was a bond protest as well. It was another sometimes raucous and always lengthy board meeting complete with one group protesting the upcoming $4.4 billion bond election and another calling for answers in the aftermath of the August death of 14-year-old Landon Payton at Marshall Middle School while in gym class. Landon's father Alexis Payton, was joined by state Rep. Christina Morales and FIEL Executive Director Cesar Espinosa among others who stood during the meeting while holding a picture of Landon.
Payton's family has still not been told of his cause of death, only that he suffered â€œa medical emergency.â€ The AED equipment was reportedly not working in his location which has led to an HISD review of AEDs throughout the district and discovering 170 inoperable units that it has said will be repaired. The family still doesn't know if a working defibrillator would have saved Landon. HISD has said that only medical officials can establish the cause of death.
Later in the public speaking section of the evening, parent Anna Luzutiaga asked everyone to stand to remember the teenager in a moment of silence. While audience members rose, the board members and superintendent did not â€“ which caused an immediate outcry.
Chanting Landon's name, while continuing to stand, the audience could not be interrupted. One audience member cursed which sparked a reprimand from Board President Audrey Momanaee who said children were watching the meeting from home. When the chanting continued, the board and Miles retreated to a back room right before 6 p.m. before returning at 6:07.
"This board supports the Payton family," Momanaee said upon their return. She then explained the need for order in school board meetings and repeated that the use of swear words could not be allowed.
An interesting note was struck when Miles discussed the districtâ€™s assessment of performance comparing non-certified teachers to certified ones. Data showed that a lower percentage of the non-certified â€“ 42 percent â€” scored at the proficient and above level, while 66 percent of certified teachers were judged proficient or higher.
In the past, Miles has maintained that teachers should be judged on the job they too, rather than whether they are certified or not. At board meetings there have been continuous complaints from parents, students and educators about the districtâ€™s increasing use of non-certified teachers, contending that many of them are ill-equipped to handle a classroom.
Thursday, Miles acknowledged the important factors of experience and training in how effective teachers can be.
He touted an expansion of HISDâ€™s own in-house certification program which allows the uncertified to work toward certification while teaching. He also referred to a Texas Tribune story which reported that districts all over the state are using more uncertified teachers, trying to fill their teacher ranks, calling it the new reality.
"This is a problem statewide and nationally," Miles said. For the forseeable future if we want to fill all of our positions, we will be hiring teachers who need a certification."
According to the Texas Education Agency, 40 percent of new hires across the state in 2023-24 were uncertified. At charter schools it was 60 percent. At the same time, Miles reported that there were 8,000 applicants at the districtâ€™s job fairs for about 1,000 openings.
An analysis of the HISD retention patterns Expand All Read in NewsBreak

author: Austin Akhilomen
title: 2025 AFCONQ: Super Eagles Condemned To Beat Benin  â€“Simon
text:
Super Eagles winger Moses Simon says the team is condemned to beat Benin in Saturdayâ€™s 2025 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers.
Recall that Nigeria will be going for revenge after losing 2-1 to Benin in a 2026 FIFA World Cup qualifier.
Speaking with NFFTV, the Nantes star stated that the Super Eagles will be desperate to overcome the Cheetah at the Godswill Akpabio International Stadium, Uyo, in a bid to put a smile on the faces of Nigerians.
â€œI missed my Super Eagles teammates, and I am happy to be back to my roots. The mood was a little bit up because coach Eguavoen knows a lot of the players and the role they have to play.
Read Also: AFCON 2025Q: Super Eagles Determined To Make Great Start â€” Eguavoen
â€œHe gave confidence to the players. Heâ€™s the coach, and we donâ€™t know his tactics or how they will work. You can find the best players sitting on the bench. So I believe the coach knows better than we do. He has not been out of the team despite the fact that heâ€™s not the coach. But heâ€™s within the team because heâ€™s working for the federation.
â€œThis is our job, and we know what is at stake. Of course, we lost against Benin 2-1, and I believe we donâ€™t want another loss or a draw against them again. I know we always beat them, and this one wonâ€™t be an exemption. The guys know what they have to do to win. We are not going there for a draw or fighting a war.
â€œWe will approach the game with the sole aim of winning and put a smile on the faces of Nigerians. As a Nigerian, we always feel sad each time the team doesnâ€™t win. Even though the players gave their best, their best may not be enough.â€

author: pipocamoderna
title: "Mufasa: O Rei LeÃ£o" lidera bilheterias de Natal nos EUA
text:
"Mufasa: O Rei LeÃ£o" lidera bilheterias de Natal nos EUA
AnimaÃ§Ã£o da Disney reage e supera "Sonic 3 - O Filme" apÃ³s desempenho fraco no fim de semana de estreia
Virada nas bilheterias durante o Natal
"Mufasa: O Rei LeÃ£o" conseguiu liderar as bilheterias de Natal nos Estados Unidos, arrecadando US$ 15 milhÃµes na quarta-feira (25/12). O desempenho marca uma virada para o filme da Disney, que havia estreado com nÃºmeros fracos no fim de semana anterior, arrecadando quase metade do que "Sonic 3 - O Filme" conquistou no mesmo perÃ­odo.
A animaÃ§Ã£o agora projeta um total de US$ 50 milhÃµes para o feriado prolongado, igualando a meta de "Sonic 3 - O Filme", mas a vantagem ainda Ã© vista como incerta, de acordo com analistas, porque a adaptaÃ§Ã£o de videogame da Paramount continua performando bem, em 2Âº lugar.
"Nosferatu" supera expectativas
Entre os destaques do feriado, o terror "Nosferatu", dirigido por Robert Eggers e estrelado por Lily-Rose Depp, Nicholas Hoult e Bill SkarsgÃ¥rd, impressionou com US$ 11,6 milhÃµes arrecadados na quarta-feira (25/12). A expectativa Ã© que o filme alcance US$ 40 milhÃµes atÃ© o domingo, bem acima das projeÃ§Ãµes iniciais, que apontavam US$ 20 milhÃµes como meta.
Outros lanÃ§amentos de destaque
A cinebiografia de Bob Dylan, "Um Completo Desconhecido", com TimothÃ©e Chalamet, atraiu o pÃºblico mais velho e arrecadou US$ 7,2 milhÃµes. O drama de Ã©poca deve encerrar o feriado com US$ 22 milhÃµes, consolidando um forte inÃ­cio.
Outro destaque Ã© "Babygirl", estrelado por Nicole Kidman, que arrecadou US$ 1,7 milhÃ£o no mesmo dia e projeta um total de US$ 7 milhÃµes para os cinco dias. JÃ¡ "O Brutalista", outro candidato ao Oscar, optou por um lanÃ§amento limitado, estreando em apenas seis salas neste fim de semana.
RecuperaÃ§Ã£o nas bilheterias de fim de ano
A temporada de fim de ano trouxe alÃ­vio para o mercado cinematogrÃ¡fico, reduzindo o dÃ©ficit anual de 11% em novembro para 4% atualmente. O desempenho foi impulsionado por sucessos como "Moana 2", "Wicked" e "Gladiador II", e agora reforÃ§ado pelo bom desempenho das estreias no Natal.

author: @andaluciainf
title: Muere un anciano y una mujer resulta herida grave en un accidente de coche en NÃ­jar | AndalucÃ­a InformaciÃ³n. Todas las noticias de AndalucÃ­a
text: Un hombre ha muerto y una mujer ha resultado herida de carÃ¡cter grave a causa de un accidente de trÃ¡fico registrado esta tarde en la carretera AL-3106 en NÃ­jar (AlmerÃ­a), segÃºn informa el servicio unificado de emergencias 112 de AndalucÃ­a. El siniestro se produjo sobre las 17.45 horas en la carretera AL-3106, en el municipio de NÃ­jar. Ambos ancianos viajaban en el mismo turismo que se saliÃ³ de la vÃ­a cuando circulaban por la carretera que va desde Las Hortichuelas a las Negras. Tras el aviso a 112 y la activaciÃ³n de los operativos, hasta el lugar se desplazaron servicios sanitarios, Guardia Civil de TrÃ¡fico, ProtecciÃ³n Civil de NÃ­jar y Mantenimiento de la VÃ­a. El hombre, de unos ochenta aÃ±os de edad, ha fallecido en el lugar del accidente mientras que a la mujer, tambiÃ©n de edad avanzada, consiguieron estabilizarla y trasladarla con vida al Hospital TorrecÃ¡rdenas. Se ha activado el protocolo judicial. EnvÃ­a tu noticia a: [participa@andaluciainformacion.es](mailto:participa@andaluciainformacion.es)
